Hey Mosh, Many thanks for this amazing tutorial. As an entrepreneur to run data-driven innovations, Python can be of great help. As a senior business analyst, it is sort of upskilling to me.

(VERY IMPORTANT TIP FOR PEOPLE WATCHING!)
   Do not try watching the entire video at once. Limit your watch time from 30 or 60 minutes each day and make sure to participate and understand the code. This will take around a week to complete, but it will save you from feeling like you're not good enough. Don't rush yourself. Limit and pay attention!

EDIT: It also helps if you take notes or take a picture of the final result of the lesson. It is very helpful to look at when you're away from your computer. If you forget, you have a chance to examine the code and see how and why things work.

The best method we have on memorizing Operator Precedence is by calling it P.E.M.D.A.S. Which means Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication, Division, Addition, Subtraction.

I hope this helps ‚ò∫

2:12:21  If you wanna use remove(x) method instead of append(x), make sure you copy the list to another variable say list1.  Because if you use only the main list, it will shorten the list according to the remove(x) method, so python interpreter will jump a few numbers.  So some of the duplicates will remove and some of them will remain unremoved. 

So use the list variable to run the loop and make changes [ remove(x) ] in the variable list1

Here's my code : 

# removes the duplicates in a list
 
list = [5, 8, 5, 4, 7, 4, 7, 3, 1, 8, 100, 100, 5, 9]
list.sort()
print(numbers)
 
list1 = list.copy()             # caution:  can't use list1 = list
value = float('-inf')
 
for x in list:
    if value == x:
        list1.remove(x)
    else:
        value = x
print(list1)

for people starting out

don't worry if you watched 5 minutes of his video and ended up practicing for 60 minutes. That's actually the most practical way to learn. Here is how i learn :

I finish two topics and then i spend time practicing both of them together, then when i learn the next topic i practice all three topics together. That way i don't forget. Don't get frustrated just slow down relax and practice and before you know it you'll be done :)

Pro tips
: If you're watching in laptop watch in cinema mode [full screen] 
Open a google docs or a word document and write some code that. you find hard to understand and then learn it step by step.
Before starting to watch the video again, review the material and revise it before learning a new topic
You can refer to his cheat sheet too! Anytime you're stuck :) You can also make your own cheat sheet :)

i know you are the one who is teaching us here, but wouldnt it be simpler NOT to have that variable there?

here is what i wrote

weight = input("Weight: ")
lbs_or_kg = input("(L)bs or (K)g: ")
 
if lbs_or_kg.upper() == "L":
    print(f"You are {float(weight) * 0.45359290943} Kg")
elif lbs_or_kg.upper() == "K":
    print(f"You are {float(weight) * 2.20462} Lbs")
else:
    print("Unit not recognized")

i think thats simpler because you dont have to define a third variable and i think this should be a little faster to run (not that it matters), but who knows, it works still so who cares

For those who will struggle like me in the project 3 (Django) to change the path of base.html in the Templates directory because in the last Django version in settings.py it doesn't "import os" anymore but have a "from pathlib import Path", the solution is :
To add "Path.joinpath(BASE_DIR, 'templates')" in TEMPLATES > 'DIRS' instead of "os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'templates')".
You're welcome ;)

Thanks for the tutorial! I have a question: how come that the '=' does not always behave the same way? If I write: 
cell1 = list[0] 
cell2 = list[0]
cell1 and cell2 are independent, since the '=' only puts the value of the right expression into the variable on the left. So modifying cell1 will not modify cell2. And it will not modify list[0] either.

However, in the excel project (4:04:00), if I write:
cell1 = sheet.cell(1, 3)
cell2 = sheet.cell(1, 3)
cell1 and cell2 are actually dependent. The '=' is doing more that just putting the value of the right expression into the variable on the left. It is creating a link between its two sides. So if I modify the value of cell2, the value of  sheet.cell(1, 3) will be automatically modified, and cell1 will also be modified, even if the instruction 'cell1 = sheet.cell(1, 3)' was previously executed by the program and not executed again to update the value of cell1.
So why the '=' is having such a different behaviour? And what determines which behaviour it should have? 
Thanks

Hi Mosh.
Please can you help me with question.
It's really difficult for me. 

Given the final percentage a student has gotten at the end of a semester, you need to write a program that decides if the student has passed or failed the semester.

If the percentage is higher than or equal to 60, the student has passed the semester. If the percentage is lower than 60, the student has failed the semester.

However, the percentage is not the only thing that determines if a student has passed or failed. A student does not pass if their score is 5 points below the class average.

For instance, if the average class score is 70, the student must have a minimum score of 65 to pass.

If the average class score is 50, the student still needs a score of 60 to pass based on our first condition.

It is interesting that the method find for String returns -1 when it cannot find the character that you are looking for.
However, then you can use index position -1 in a String to find a character.
Therefore you cannot directly use the result from find to retrieve the character at an index position.
But -1 is the position of the last character of the string...

I am aware that "find" is a method, but Python allows position -1. Even when this is right, I find that for a string this is a bit inconsistent :)
